Award.AwardTitle: NSF East Asia and Pacific Summer Institute (EAPSI) for FY 2013 in Japan
Award.AbstractNarration:
This action funds Robert Zinna of Washington State University to conduct a research project in Biology during the summer of 2013 at the Niimi laboratory at Nagoya University in Nagoya, Japan. The project title is "Diversification of Weapon Form: Insights from Development of Horned Beetles." The host scientist is Dr. Teruyuki Niimi.

Robert Zinna is PhD student in Entomology at Washington State University who studies the development and evolution of insect morphology, specifically morphology that has been adapted into weapons. Understanding the origins of new morphologies is one of the critical challenges of evolutionary biology. Using a combination of classical developmental biology techniques as well as new high-throughput methodologies, this project is investigating patterning mechanisms that contribute to weapon development using an insect model. The outcomes of this work will advance the understanding of the proximate mechanisms of evolutionary biology

Broader impacts of an EAPSI fellowship include providing the Fellow a first-hand research experience outside the U.S.; an introduction to the science, science policy, and scientific infrastructure of the respective location; and an orientation to the society, culture and language. These activities meet the NSF goal to educate for international collaborations early in the career of its scientists, engineers, and educators, thus ensuring a globally aware U.S. scientific workforce. The scientific results of this fellowship will be disseminated through peer-reviewed scientific publications that involve not only the EAPSI host, Dr. Niimi, but also the Fellow's PhD advisor, Dr. Lavine, and a third collaborator, Dr. Emlen. This project facilitates international dissemination of research and research techniques, and allows the Fellow to share novel teaching methods with international science educators as well as learn from their methods. The ability to incorporate an international perspective when teaching science is an important step in increasing diversity in scientific literacy. The Fellow is also heavily involved in entomological and scientific outreach to a diverse audience at Washington State University, and the strong pro-insect culture present in Japan allows him to develop new methods of community outreach for Entomology, focusing on how insects can make educational house pets for all levels of K-12 education.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The evolution of new body forms is one of the most interesting questions in evolutionary biology. Japanese Rhinoceros beetles (Trypoxylus dichotomus) are good targets to investigate this question, as they possess an amazing body modification. Male beetles are equipped with a gigantic horn on the top of their head, which they use to battle other males over females. This weapon is a new body form known as an evolutionary novelty. Evolutionary novelties are new body forms that share no resemblance with other parts of the organism’s body, such as the eyespots on butterfly wings and the antlers of deer.

 

The EAPSI award ID 1311025 to Robert Zinna funded investigation into the molecular mechanisms that govern the evolution of novel body forms, specifically the weapons of this beetle. The award funded research to test the hypothesis that new body forms arise as a result of recruiting existing genes to new function. In addition this award funded the establishment of collaboration between the laboratories of three researchers- two in America and one in Japan.

 

The research carried out provided preliminary evidence that the head horns in Rhinoceros beetles do not appear to utilize existing genes during their development. RNA knockdowns of genes traditionally involved in growth and development of limbs did not visibly change the horn shape in adults. However, further validation of these results is necessary to determine the true role the candidate genes play in this organism. The research also established stages of growth for the horn tissue, which will aid in future research of the mechanisms underlying the formation of this structure.
